I worked for a couple summers at a plant nursery/green house, a big climate controlled place that was pretty cool (actually hot while working during the summer lol, but I was out of direct sun on a production line preparing plant cuttings for propagation by rooting.) They used these predatory mites to defeat spider mites there too, on all sorts of landscaping and ornamental plants! I remember a presentation they gave all us workers about the mites, because we were encouraged to report any potential infestations of mites or aphids or anything else and their location in the greenhouses or fields if we saw any while working. If we were unsure we were still supposed to report them, as they had records of where they had already deployed the predatory ones, so it wouldn't really create a false alarm. They just didn't want anyone freaking out and spraying pesticides on our allied troops lol. My eyesight is good enough that I could see the spider-like shape of both the bad and good mites, but the color is what really stands out of course.
